Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chiguy Met with my urologist/surgeon today, and after discussing the issue of a continually rising PSA in the face of several biopsies finding only 1 or 2 cores of G6 cancer, he suggested trying Finasteride (Proscar). The way I understand it, it should lower my PSA by 50% in 3 months time. If not successful by then, it should achieve the 50% reduction within 6 months or there is a likelihood of a more aggressive cancer. Also, if, after whatever reduction is seen, there is ANY increase in PSA, it's also an indication of something more serious than a G6 and would likely require treatment. I understand that reducing the PSA is NOT eliminating any cancer. The way I understand this strategy is that it will eliminate any possibility that there is an issue of BPH, even though my prostate is not enlarged outwardly. (I have also been taking Alfuzosin since September '17) It will allow us to be more certain of a missed aggressive cancer if the PSA continues to rise. The 'risk' to this path, as I see it, is that I am allowing an aggressive cancer 6 months growth time. Is this an accurate understanding on my part? I spoke to my urologist about this about six weeks ago. He didn't recommend it at that time saying it could mask what was going on. He's still as confused as I am about what is going on with my case. I've got my follow-up next week Thursday to see my next step.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old November 2011 - 1.2 PSA June 2014 - 3.6 PSA October 2015 - 4.5 PSA November 2015 - 4.7 PSA Feb 2016 - 6.1 PSA March 2016 - 12 core biopsy with all negative October 2017 - 11.3 PSA November 2017 - 15.6 PSA December 2017 - MRI - PI-RADS 5: THERE IS A DISCRETE AREA OF T2 SIGNAL HYPOINTENSITY AND RESTRICTED DIFFUSION IN THE LEFT ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE TRANSITIONAL ZONE/ANTERIOR FIBROMUSCULAR STROMA NEAR THE APEX, CONCERNING FOR PROSTATE MALIGNANCY. Posts.Title: Doc prescribed Finasteride (Proscar) today - questions...

Posts.Content: I have had prostate infections several times in the past with the most recent flare-up about 2 years ago. A round of Cipro seemed to clear it up or at least caused my symptoms to go away. I was under for this MRI guided biopsy so it was much more pleasant than the first. The Surgeon did make a comment to my wife that he saw nothing on the ultrasound and if he didn't have the MRI data the suspect area would never have been sampled. He also said that he's seen cases like mine before but they are very rare.
Posts.Title: High PSA and no cancer detected

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lastchance I had two negative biopsies, a MRI , and a PCA3 test and they all indicated I did not have cancer. At the time my PSA was 24. The uro that did these test did not want to do anything else unless it went up ten points. I went to another URO six months later (as quick as I could get in) and he suggested a saturation biopsy, which I was all for. PSA ended up at 40. Saturation biopsy was about like the other two with the exception of being put under. I did/do ( first post surgery PSA is in March) have cancer G7, (3+4) in three of the 26 samples. I had been dealing with this for about two years and already decided I was going to have surgery if it cam to that. Surgery was 12/4/2017 and I could not be happier. Prostate was 67 grams and the doctor is pretty sure it was confined, not trying to be pessimistic but I would push for the saturation biopsy, I wished they had done mine about a year earlier. Good luck,it can be a long road with a lot of decisions , I truly wish you the best as I have been there and done that. Thanks for your response. Did anything show up on your MRI? Like I said they saw a small area on mine and sampled that area heavily. I really have no other symptoms at this time other than the increasing PSA.
Posts.Title: High PSA and no cancer detected

Posts.Content: I am 55 years old and I recently had an MRI assisted biopsy and all the results were negative. This is what was on the MRI report; IMPRESSION: PI-RADS 5: THERE IS A DISCRETE AREA OF T2 SIGNAL HYPOINTENSITY AND RESTRICTED DIFFUSION IN THE LEFT ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE TRANSITIONAL ZONE/ANTERIOR FIBROMUSCULAR STROMA NEAR THE APEX, CONCERNING FOR PROSTATE MALIGNANCY. The doctor removed 3 samples from the suspect area on the MRI as well as 12 additional from the rest of the prostate. He said my prostate is 33 grams in size. Here's some of my history; PSA History November 2011 - 1.2 June 2014 - 3.6 October 2015 - 4.5 November 2015 - 4.7 Feb 2016 - 6.1 October 2017 - 11.3 November 2017 - 15.6 There are some other PSA results that I haven't listed here but they are all in line showing a steady increase in level. I had a traditional ultrasound guided biopsy in March 2016 with 12 samples and all were negative. I have none of other usual symptoms associated with BPH or prostate cancer. The doctor is recommending another PSA test in 3 months and maybe another MRI after that. Any other advice?
Posts.Title: High PSA and no cancer detected

Posts.Content: No history of VD but I did have a colonoscopy in October 2015.
Posts.Title: High PSA and no cancer detected

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone, I'll post the results when I have them.

Posts.Title: ConfirmMDX test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JJO I had a Confirm MDX test for free because my doc is participating in their trial. They look at DNA from non-cancerous prostate cells and give you two percentages: one, the likelihood that you have cancer that was undetected, and the likelihood that your cancer is aggressive. In my case, I already knew that I had cancer, but it was nice to see the very low percentage for aggressiveness. My doc says the early results from the trial are encouraging. However, this test is just one rather minor piece of information. No one would make any treatment decisions based on it. The primary goal of the test, I think, is to decide who needs a repeat biopsy when the first one was negative, but the PSA has continued to go up. Thanks, I'm just looking for more direction. I've now had two negative biopsies including one MRI guided biopsy. Anything that can point me in the right direction helps.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old November 2011 - 1.2 PSA June 2014 - 3.6 PSA October 2015 - 4.5 PSA November 2015 - 4.7 PSA Feb 2016 - 6.1 PSA March 2016 - 12 core biopsy with all negative October 2017 - 11.3 PSA November 2017 - 15.6 PSA December 2017 - MRI - PI-RADS 5: THERE IS A DISCRETE AREA OF T2 SIGNAL HYPOINTENSITY AND RESTRICTED DIFFUSION IN THE LEFT ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE TRANSITIONAL ZONE/ANTERIOR FIBROMUSCULAR STROMA NEAR THE APEX, CONCERNING FOR PROSTATE MALIGNANCY. December 2017 - MRI guided biopsy (3 cores in target area and 12 others) all negative February 2018 - ConfirmMDX test on recent biopsy samples are all negative April 2018 - 12.2 PSA July 2018 - 14.2 PSA Oct 2018 - 14.6 PSA

Posts.Title: What experience do you folks have with ConfirmMDx

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by edwardtyme Hello- My name is Edward From Florida and I'd sincerely appreciate any advice / guidance some here may provide: I'm a healthy 59 year old male with an increasing PSA reading over the last 5 years. Back in 2013 my PSA reading was at 4.6 and it steadily increased over the years to a current reading of 17.5 which was verified as my blood work taken twice over 5 weeks. I have had three negative biopsies and 18 months ago I had an MRI which indicated a two small mass with a PIRADS score of 4. I believe my urologist, that is also a part-time assistant Professor of Urology at a major medical school in Florida will suggest yet another biopsy. Any suggestions ??? Anything different you would do if you were in my predicament ? Thanks, Edward God Bless Kind of sounds like me Edward. You can see my details in my signature. Right now I'm waiting for everything to heal from my December 29th biopsy to have another PSA check. I'm pushing for PHI and/or free PSA which has never been tested before in my case. I've been told another MRI might be in my future followed by another biopsy.

Posts.Title: I Am A Bit of A Unicorn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dth32 What does that mean? Well, we have been tracking my PSA for nearly a year now and it has not dropped below 14 during that time. In September I had an MRI that found two nodules in the right portion of my prostate. In November I had an external biopsy and from what I have read from others experience this seems to be the way to go. I was asleep and then I woke up. I had the blood in the urine of course but didn't have to go through being awake with the noises and knowing others were in the room with everything in the open Well my results came back and they found the two nodules that were Gleason 6 3+3. I think my signature explains it. Now to the unicorn.. My doctor hasn't seen anyone with my results, meaning my PSA is so high and my Gleason is 6. This is very abnormal, maybe a 1% or less of cases and he hasn't seen it. He performs the surger 5-7 times a week and has seen countless patients but hasn't seen someone my age(49) with these symptoms. So, I am a bit of a Unicorn. My wife and I went in today fully expecting to opt for surgery but the doctor wants to bring the case to his whole department. I feel like an episode of House honestly. We told him that our choice is for surgery and he said that is one of the options and one he would be leaning towards. I am just rambling on now because I just wanted to put things down in words here. Maybe someone else has seen something like this on this forum. I suppose I have a little more stress since a doctor that has seen thousands of these cases has never seen this before. What is lurking in me that they haven't seen before? It's back to the wait and see game... Dth32 Well, if you are a unicorn I wouldn't know what to call myself other than lucky maybe at this point or confused. Anyway, good luck to both of us.
Posts.Signature: 55 years old November 2011 - 1.2 PSA June 2014 - 3.6 PSA October 2015 - 4.5 PSA November 2015 - 4.7 PSA Feb 2016 - 6.1 PSA March 2016 - 12 core biopsy with all negative October 2017 - 11.3 PSA November 2017 - 15.6 PSA December 2017 - MRI - PI-RADS 5: THERE IS A DISCRETE AREA OF T2 SIGNAL HYPOINTENSITY AND RESTRICTED DIFFUSION IN THE LEFT ANTERIOR ASPECT OF THE TRANSITIONAL ZONE/ANTERIOR FIBROMUSCULAR STROMA NEAR THE APEX, CONCERNING FOR PROSTATE MALIGNANCY. Posts.Title: I Am A Bit of A Unicorn

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PCASpouse 1. Short version: I read a paper from UT Dallas Djin cited from 2017 that showed 38% of pts whose first bx was an MRI guided bx of Pirads 5 lesions which were negative were then found to have significant PCA on subsequent either bx or prostatectomy, so these were false negative MRI guided bxs. There were some differences with DH other than the Pirads5: average age ten years older, average PSA 9 ( but wide variance), and though authors did not give ethnicity, likely a lot of African Americans, who have a higher bad PCA risk. This is me in a nutshell except I'm not of African decent. I also had the ConfirMDx test which showed no signs of cancer. Had another PSA a month ago and I'm still hovering around 12. Going to repeat PSA in June/July and then decide on another MRI and MRI guided biopsy. I understand it's hard not knowing but you just go on with life and live every day to the fullest.
